Take Five solves the horrific first world problem of “listening to silence for over two hours”. I can’t even imagine how people lived before the release of Take Give. Very pretty website and icon though.

§ Mar 31st, 2011

Facebook runs on a very stiff, crude model of what people are like. It herds everybody — friends, co-workers, romantic partners, that guy who lived on your block but moved away after fifth grade — into the same big room. It smooshes together your work self and your home self, your past self and your present self, into a single generic extruded product. It suspends the natural process by which old friends fall away over time, allowing them to build up endlessly, producing the social equivalent of liver failure. On Facebook, there is one kind of relationship: friendship, and you have it with everybody. You’re friends with your spouse, and you’re friends with your plumber.

I’ve been looking for this quote from Lev Grossman’s profile on Mark Zuckerberg for Time for ages. That one paragraph sums up what’s wrong with Facebook better than any analysis I’ve seen or read anywhere. Perfect.

Via Lachlan Hardy.

Introducing TumblrThemr →

A succinct explanation by Max Wheeler of how TumblrThemr works. I think the whole thing is very clever and I’m quite proud of the code I wrote for the XML to JSON conversion.

§ Mar 24th, 2011

For the past few months the guys from Icelab (particularly, Max Wheeler) and I have been working on something to solve a personal itch: the lack of local Tumblr theme development.

It’s not a 100% complete solution and the hoops we’ve jumped through to make it work as well is it does are large and plentiful but I can attest that TumblrThemr makes developing Tumblr themes a hell of a lot more enjoyable.

§ Mar 23rd, 2011

Fancy Hands →

For $35/month Fancy Hands, “Personal Assistant for Everyone”, can do 15 tasks of this nature (taken from their 10 most commonly requested tasks:

  • Restaurant Reservations
  • Scheduling a car service / taxi pickup
  • Schedule a haircut with [stylist] on Friday after 1pm
  • Find a couple upholsterer options near where I work
  • Call some hotel and extend my stay for three nights instead of two

Seems to me that you’re paying $35/month to send 15 emails instead of making 15 phone calls or doing 15 Google searches. Typing “Upholsterer near X location” into Google Maps is initially faster than sending a coherent email and not only will the results be returned instantly but they’re interactive. As for booking a taxi, a haircut or changing a hotel reservation these are 30 second phone calls which resolve instantly.

Legitimately time saving and useful stuff like picking up laundry, recurring tasks or even the graphical theme of their website — a bellhop carrying bags — they can’t do. I imagine the real advantage of a personal assistant would come from tight integration with your life. Things like the ability to go places for you, fill out your calendar, read your email and buy things are all outside the realm of Fancy Hands.

Maybe people are willing to pay $35/month for the illusion of a personal assistant.

§ Mar 22nd, 2011

The Dickbar →

Neven Mrgan in response to and in support of Marco Arment:

I don’t know what Twitter should focus on instead, and it doesn’t look like they do, either.

How about they focus on posting your own tweets and reading tweets written by those you’re explicitly interested in. Too obvious?

§ Mar 21st, 2011

The real message of new NYTimes digital pricing: “For the love of Christ, just let us drop some paper on your porch every day.

Scott Simpson on the New York Times’ new, way-too-complicated pay wall.

For 150 years the NY Times has been selling their content for a price. It’s always been very simple: buy an issue or a subscription, get the content. The incredibly hard time they’re having transferring this model to their website makes no sense to me. The distinction between “traditional” computers, mobile phones and tablet computers is ridiculous. If the relatively recent introduction of these new mediums teaches media moguls anything it should be that medium is irrelevant.

§ Mar 20th, 2011

And Another Thing

I understand that they’re different departments and it really makes no sense to halt one part of your “business” while another struggles when your goal obviously isn’t to make money.

But, that doesn’t stop things like the new explore page, exursions to SXSW and some hipster poetry thing pissing me off when core shit like serving content reliably isn’t happening.

§ Mar 19th, 2011

Maniacal Rage: Please, Let Me Pay

Maniacal Rage: Please, Let Me Pay

Garrett Murray:

But here’s the thing, folks: I’ve been complaining for years that Tumblr is free. I don’t want it to be free. I want to pay for it. Tumblr is one of the few services on earth that refuses to take my money.

I feel exactly the same way. Money in exchange for reliability is a much better deal than free with downtime. I truly don’t understand the desire to give something away for free at any cost and when it’s at the cost of actually providing the thing you want to provide for free the whole situation is absurd.

This reminds me of something I wrote a year ago about This American Life begging the listeners of their free podcast to donate money to offset the huge cost of providing the podcast for free. It don’t make no damn sense.

Ironing →

I’ve linked to this sublime video before but after watching it again today I can’t help but post it again. Even if you hate ironing (which I don’t, I love it) you can appreciate watching someone use the right tools to complete a job with precision and speed. I’d love to know where you can get an ironing board (desk?) and iron setup like that.

§ Feb 27th, 2011

From Jessie Char’s What Your 16-Hour Workday Says About You!:

  • You’re a really hard worker
  • Your time is poorly managed
  • You don’t know what to do with your life
  • Your boss knows you’re gullible
  • At least 40% of your diet consists of pre-packaged food
  • You send out work emails at inappropriate hours
  • You have no perspective on life
  • You don’t sleep enough for proper brain function
  • You have very little self-respect
  • Your salary should be higher, but isn’t
  • You drink either too much or not enough 

This couldn’t be more accurate although I say it applies to a 10-hour as much as a 16-hour workday. “You have no perspective on life” is the most striking. Despite years of it not actually working, the workoholics I know seem to be driving themselves into the ground at the expense of everything else as a means to get to some mythical place not even they can discern. I have no respect for these people.
